did.unittitle: Scaliger family papers, fifteenth-nineteenth centuries
did.abstract: The Scaliger Family Papers, when taken together, trace the history of a noble family that was originally from Italy but lived primarily in Agen, France from the mid-1500s through the mid-1800s. Beginning with the patriarch, Julius Caesar Scaliger (1484-1558), a celebrated Italian scholar and physician, the members of the Scaliger family upheld an illustrious reputation over the centuries as scholars, military leaders, and noblemen. Throughout their family’s history, the Scaligers maintained that they were descended from the Della Scallas, Princes of Verona. It is as a result of the necessity to defend this claim as well as later attempts to prove their ties to their noble heritage that this collection of documents has remained so well intact. The Scaliger Family Papers is a collection that encompasses several different kinds of documents that span from 1539 to 1862 including letters, genealogical material, works by members of the Scaliger family, as well as military, legal, and financial documents.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Scaliger Family Papers, when taken together, trace the history of a noble family that was originally from Italy but lived primarily in Agen, France from the mid-1500s through the mid-1800s. Beginning with the patriarch, Julius Caesar Scaliger (1484-1558), a celebrated Italian scholar and physician, the members of the Scaliger family upheld an illustrious reputation over the centuries as scholars, military leaders, and noblemen. Throughout their family’s history, the Scaligers maintained that they were descended from the Della Scallas, Princes of Verona. It is perhaps as a result of the necessity to defend this claim as well as later attempts to prove ties to their noble heritage that this collection of papers has remained so well intact. This, in part, helps to explain why Mademoiselle Victoire de Vérone, the last surviving legitimate heir of the Scaliger family, still possessed the papers of her family dating back as early as the 1530s even though she was living in poverty.

In order to truly understand this collection it is important to first consider the founder of the family, Julius Caesar Scaliger. Over the course of his lifetime, Julius Caesar Scaliger engaged in a wide variety of pursuits. According to his own account, he began as a page in the court of Emperor Maximilian. From there, he became a soldier and was later even knighted for several acts of bravery. But, it was not for his military career that Scaliger was best known. It was rather his work as a scholar and physician that garnered him the most fame. As a young man Scaliger moved from Italy to Agen, a small town in the south of France. It was in Agen that he established a school, built a medical practice, and started a family. Overtime, Scaliger’s medical teachings became well-known as part of a revolt against strict adherence to ancient writings. He also became famous for his poetry as well as an oration he wrote violently denouncing the work of Erasmus. During the last years of his life, Scaliger worked on his most well-known book, Poetics. Published after his death, this book marked the first attempt to develop a philosophical theory of poetry. Julius Caesar Scaliger died on October 28, 1558, leaving behind a powerful legacy for his family to follow.

Despite Julius Caesar Scaliger’s profound accomplishments, his son, Joseph Juste Scaliger (1540-1609), is considered to have eclipsed his father’s fame with his work as a religious leader and scholar known for expanding the commonly held notions of classical history. It was Joseph Juste Scaliger who publically forwarded the claim that his family was descended from the Princes of Verona in his book Epistola de Vetustate et Splendore Gentis Scaligerae et J.C. Scaligeri Vita. He was attacked for this supposition and responded in later books to defend his claims to nobility, a practice his family would continue most notably in the 1660s and 1670s.

Nobility afforded many privileges in France during the seventeenth century and, as a result, many people began to issue false claims of noble birth. Consequently, King Louis XIV issued a declaration in 1666 requiring a verification of noble titles throughout the realm. In response, Joseph de Charrier de Lescale de Vérone (?-1689), head of the Scaliger family at the time, began to collect proof of the nobility of his ancestors and therefore himself. It is this necessity to verify the nobility of his lineage that is perhaps what brought this collection of papers together in the first place. As a result of his extensive compilation of documents as well as a series of numbered letters stating his claims, not only did the king accept Joseph’s petition for nobility, but also he officially recognized the Lescales of Verona as descendants of the Princes of Verona, as Joseph Juste Scaliger had asserted more than fifty years before.

In 1847 the last surviving heir of the Scaliger family legacy, Victoire de Vérone, was living destitute and alone in the same château in Agen that Julius Caesar Scaliger had originally built to house his growing family more than three hundred years before. Resigned to a life of poverty, it came as a shock to Victoire when she received a visit from Monsieur Jean Robert Poizat (1803-1868)who claimed that he was distantly related to her and, as a result, also a descendant of the Scaliger family. It appears that Victoire’s father had left his family in France to look after his wife’s property in Santo Domingo. There, unbeknownst to his wife in France, he had developed a relationship with another woman from which two children were born one being Jean Robert Poizat’s mother making Poizat, albeit distantly and illegitimately, related to Victoire. In return for the promise of money, Jean Robert Poizat requested the papers and documents of the Scaliger family in order to obtain official recognition of his lineage. Victoire, desperate for financial aid, agreed and, following a series of letters, the papers of the Scaliger family, collected since the mid-1500s, changed hands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection encompasses several different kinds of documents that span from the mid-1500s through the mid-1800s including letters, genealogical material, works by members of the Scaliger family, as well as military, legal, and financial documents.

There are three broad categories of correspondence within the collection. The first is a series of letters dating from 1609 to 1735. They are all addressed to Monsieur de Vérone a agen but because it is such an ambiguous title it is unclear specifically which member of the family the letter belongs to. As a result, this group of letters is from several different senders, in markedly different handwritings, and probably intended for different people. The second category of correspondence is the letters of Joseph de Charrier de Lescale de Vérone (?-1689). The bulk of these letters are a numbered correspondence whereby Joseph verifies his claims to the Lescale name supported by the legal documents he amassed as proof. The final group of correspondence is addressed to Jean Robert Poizat (1803-1868) and records his attempts to obtain recognition of his lineage through support from Victoire de Vérone and the validation of the Count de Magne of the College of Heralds.

Genealogical material represents another important component of this collection. It includes notes and lists, family trees, and drawings of family crests. These documents trace fragments of the lineage of not only the Scaligers but also other families closely related to them such as the Montaults, Monmejans, and the Bousquets. These connections, especially as they represent the ties to nobility, are further reinforced throughout the rest of the collection especially within the military, legal, and financial documents.

The works by members of the Scaliger family also reflect this preoccupation with family ancestry and many of the works record the history of the family and question its origins. These often sewn together sheaths of paper synthesize the genealogical notes and drawings as well as the legal documents that marked the passing of arms and noble titles through wills and marriage certificates.

The final and most varied series of documents within the collection are the military, legal, and financial documents, which includes contracts, death certificates, wills, orders from the King of France, agreements, marriage contracts, baptism certificates, and even the receipt for the shipment of the case of documents containing the Scaliger family papers from Mademoiselle Victoire de Vérone in Agen to Jean Robert Poizat in Paris. It is these documents that officially verify the connections, suppositions, and rights asserted within the correspondence, genealogical notes, and works by the members of the Scaliger family.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See also: article by Warren E. Blake: Joseph Justus Scaliger, pp. 83-91 (The Classical Journal , Vol. 36, No. 2, November 1940)

article by Vernon Hall, Jr: Scaliger Family Papers, pp.120-123 (Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society, Vol. 92, No.2, Studies of Historical Documents in the Library of the American Philosophical Society, May 5 1948)
article by Vernon Hall, Jr: Life of Julius Caesar Scaliger (1484-1558), pp. 85-170 (Transactions of the American Philosophical Society , New Series, Vol. 40, No. 2, 1950)
book by George W. Robinson: Autobiography of Joseph Scaliger (Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1927)

odd.head: African American History note
odd.p: Poizat family manuscripts, which include lists of slaves in Santo Domingo and baptismal certificates, may be of interest to scholars of African American history.

odd.head: Early American History note
odd.p: This large collection contains the family papers of the Scaligers, a prominent French family that eventually immigrated to Philadelphia in the mid-nineteenth century. The collection contains a wealth of information on the history and genealogy of this family. Some of the documents date to the fifteenth century. There is a notable amount of documents from the seventeenth and nineteenth centuries. The portion of the collection from the earlier period is mostly composed of legal documents. The nineteenth century documents are mostly correspondence. All of the documents appear to be in French or Latin. Most of these documents are beyond the scope of the early American guide, but there are some documents from Santo Domingo that relate to the family’s interest in a slave plantation there.

did.unittitle: Series I. Correspondence
Subseries A. de Verone a agen letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a series of letters dating from 1609 to 1735. While they are all addressed to Monsieur de Verone a agen, it is an ambiguous title making it unclear specifically which member of the family the letter belongs to. As a result, they are from several different senders and probably intended for several different people.

Letter from Prince Thomas de Savoye to de S'Escalle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prince Thomas of Savoye is noted as being General of the Armies of the King in Itlay and the letter is addressed to de S'Escalle Lientent au regiment de Normandie. Both Joseph Juste de Charrier de Lescale de Vérone and his son Joseph de Charrier de Lescale de Vérone served in the military so it is likely that the letter was intended for either one of them.

All of these papers are inside of a folder made of a more modern looking white lined piece of paper that reads "No 7 pas très important."

did.unittitle: Subsubseries A. Individually numbered letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note: letters numbered 3 and 4 are missing so as a result there are 44 numbered letters in total

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These are a series of numbered letters written by Joseph de Charrier de Lescale de Verone (great, great grandson of Julius Ceasar Scaliger) in support of his claims to the Lescale name. According to Vernon Hall Jr in his essay, The Scaliger Family Papers, these claims fell into three broad categories: (1) that he had borne arms for the King and recieved a commission in the regiment of Candal and that further his father too had borne arms in the armies of the king; (2) that the house of Lescale de Verone decended from the Princes of Verona; (3) that he had the right to the name of Lescale for he legally recieved it through his father from his grandmother, Anne de Lescale. The addresses on the letters vary slightly over time and are noted in the Scope and Contents note.

did.unittitle: Letter from Montaut
Letter from l'abbé
Subseries C. Jean Robert Poizat letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As Vernon Hall Jr. writes in his essay, The Scaliger Family Papers, "This is a series of letters which passed between the last of the true Scaligers, Mlle Victoire de Vérone and Monsieur and Madame Poizat of the illegitimate branch. These letters tell the story of the transfer of documents to the hands of the Poizats, Mlle Victoire's pathetic appeals for financial aid, and the history of the Poizats' efforts through the Count de Magne of the College of Heralds to obtain recognition of their pretentions."

did.unittitle: Subsubseries A. Count de Magne of Collége Héraldique de France correspondence with Jean Robert Poizat

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Count de Magne was a member of Collége Héraldique de France and all of the letters are written on its letterhead. This correspondence records Jean Robert Poizat's attempts to have the College of Heralds recognize his relation to the Scaliger family. There are a few letters within this collection from the Marquis de Magne, Collége Héraldique et Archéologisque de France but the members of the board are almost the same as that of the Collége Héraldique de France and the letterhead is similar so it is most likely the same person or closely connected to the Count de Magne.

did.unittitle: Marriage Contract
Document

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document is actually two packets of paper tied together. A note at the end of the first packet reads, "par l'arrest de la cour de parlement et chambre de guiennel." It names several members of the Scaliger family including Joseph de L'escalle Charrier, Anne de Lescalle, and Julles Caesar de Lescalle as well as legal documents including wills.

The second packet of papers is dated 1625 September 4 and is written in a similar handwriting to the first packet. It too names members of the Scaliger family and legal documents. Both packets contain notes in the margins and underlined portions at times in a different ink color than the text.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document can be found in Oversize Box 3.

did.unittitle: Collection of documents- photographed copies

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of eight photographs taken of original documents created from 1765 April 8 to 1825 June 3. The handwriting is, at times, difficult to read but the documents seem to relate most directly to Mademoiselle Victoire de Vérone and her immediate family, including her mother and her inheritance in Santo Domingo.
These documents were grouped in the same original folder as "Documents relating to the slaves belonging to the Lescale de Verone family- copies"

scopecontent.p: See also, "Document 5"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This manuscript begins with the words, "Je Blaise de Bearn" and as a result could be a personal testimony. It is a small packet of papers (about six inches by eight inches) written in a looping cursive. Some sentances are underlined.

did.unittitle: Document 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: See also, "Document 8"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document is a single sheet of parchment that looks like some of the earlier documents and "Document 8." It begins with the same "sachent tous."

did.unittitle: Document 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: See also, "Document 6"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document is a small sheet of paper with a short paragraph or block text written on it. The first line mentions "Julle de Lescale." The handwriting seems most similar to the earlier manuscripts and looks like "Document 6."

did.unittitle: Document 4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There is a note on the back, which seems to read, "a quit par lequel fait foy du rachat de la rante de ma grant maison a la porte a georga." The document also begins with the name Francois.

did.unittitle: Document 5

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: See also, "Document 1," which also references de Bern

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document begins by mentioning the de Bern family from Italy. The years 1259 and 1371 are mentioned as well as the "famille noble de Verone", Scaligeros, and members of the de Scala family. This document could be forming connections between the Scaliger family and their predecessors in Italy.

did.unittitle: Document 6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: See also, "Document 3"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document looks similar to "Document 3." It mentions de Lescale and Agen.

did.unittitle: Document 7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document begins by naming noble Joseph de Lescale and "son plainte." Without a date it is difficult to know which Joseph de Lescale the document references. It also mentions other members of the Scaliger family including Julius Caesar de Lescale. It is signed Joseph de Lascale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document can be found in Oversize Box 5.

did.unittitle: Document 8

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Like "Document 2" this document is written on parchment and begins with "sachent tous"
See also, "Document 2"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document can be found in Oversize Box 5.

did.unittitle: Document 9

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document is addressed "A Monsieur le Saneschal d'Agennois d'ascoigne...pour le Roy..." There are two paragraphs (perhaps two different messages) written on this same sheet of paper in two different ink colors and two different handwriting.

did.unittitle: Document 10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are two different paragraphs written on the same piece of paper. While the handwriting looks the same the second paragraph is in a slightly lighter color ink. Agen is mentioned.

did.unittitle: Document 11

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The document begins with "la partie de Joseph de Lescalle escuyer..." and also mentions Anne de Lescalle, his mother daughter of Julius Caesar de Lescalle, as well as the will of Julius Caesar de Lescale. It is a small booklet of fourteen sheets of paper tied together with string. Some passages of the text are underlined and there are numbers written in the margins.

controlaccess.persname: Charrier de Lescale de Vérone, Joseph Juste de
Lescale de Vérone, Anne de, after 1528-1619

did.unittitle: Document 12

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document is written in Latin on parchment and at one time had a seal attached to it. It mentions, in bold, Sylvium Cesarem Schaligerum, which could be a reference to Sylvius, Julius Caesar Scaliger's first son. It looks very similar to "Document 13."
See also, "Document 13"

did.unittitle: Document 13

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document looks very similar to "Document 12." It too is written on parchment in Latin and mentions, in bold, Sylvium Cesarem Scaligerum, which could be a reference to Sylvius, Julius Caesar Scaliger's first son.

did.unittitle: Document 14

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are two sheets of paper within this folder. The first is ripped at the bottom cutting off the end of the text. The other also has a rip in the middle of it but it does not seem to eliminate any text. Both documents mention the king.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document can be found in Oversize Box 5.

did.unittitle: Document 15

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a large rectangle of parchment. There is a small drawing at the bottom and it looks similar to several of the other oversize documents dating from the early 1500s found in Oversize Box 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document can be found in Oversize Box 5.

did.unittitle: Document 16

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a large rectangular shaped sheet of parchment with three small drawings at the bottom that could be family insignia. It looks similar to several of the other oversize documents dating from the early 1500s found in Oversize Box 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document can be found in Oversize Box 5.

did.unittitle: Document 17

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This item can be found in the Scaliger Family Papers drawer in the Map Room in the Subbasement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a rectangular sheet of parchment with drawings at the bottom that could be family insignias.
